`"Alright," you say. "Alright. Let's talk about the thing you saw. What can you tell me about it? When and how does it arrive? What does it do?"

She shudders, a full body quiver. "My visions, I. I cannot see it, or anything it does. I can see the aftermath. The worst of it." Oriko licks her cracked lips again, a sudden flash of pink on her still pale face, and she turns to Homura. "You, dead. Kaname Madoka, dead."`

lines.content:
Oriko shakes her head frantically, and then winces, putting her hand to the side of her neck. "If Miki Sayaka wasn't moved, she would be dead in..." Her eyes unfocus for a moment. "Two...? weeks."

"What?" you demand. "How- no, I'm guessing you can't tell me."

"I cannot. If I try to look... A blanked spot, and then... Miki Sayaka's corpse. Completely unblemished," she mutters, eyes distant and brows furrowed. "It doesn't happen now that she's not at home."

lines.author: All Witches' Night

lines.content: `As I watched the series and followed the relationship of Taiga and Ryuji, I noticed that their end realization mirrored my own life and my own relationship to Christ, in a sense. How often do I just see Christ as a stepping stone into something better? How often do I treat God like a sort of heavenly genie, only there to make my life better when I’m feeling needy or down? It’s unfair to Him for me to see Him only as a means to my own self-betterment, but all too often I find myself doing just that.`

lines.author: onmarble
lines.content:
Sabrina should definitely not throw the world down the drain for her own emotional gain. I don't think she will. She's too stable, too sane to do that.

Yes, if she lost Mami, she would go into depression, but I definitely see Sabrina as above the average in many things, and normal, real people can manage with loss, deal with it and move on. Sabrina can do as well.

You're definitely worrying too much about Sabrina considering Mami to be 'the important one'. That's completely natural and healthy as long as those feelings don't get twisted into some yandere madness.

lines.author: onmarble
lines.content: Don't forget Mami and Sabrina reinforce each other's good points. Maybe a little too much, they're both heroic fools after all

lines.author: All Witches' Night
lines.content:
The worry isn't about Sabrina's current mental state.  She could deal.

The worry is if she gets too reliant on Mami.  If we waifu her too hard, and we turn into another Homura.  It's an unlikely logical extreme of the current sentiment.

lines.author: All Witches' Night
lines.content:
Hm.  The current arguments in the thread about Sayaka shipping and Kyousuke have made me think a bit about his character, and now I kinda feel sorry for the guy.

AFAICT, he sees his skill with the violin as the only good thing about himself.  He seems incapable of comprehending people liking him for who he is and not what he can do.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Magical forensic science is 90% of modern detective shows because it can drive an *entertaining narrative*. CSI has crap storytelling and nobody ever talks about its characters. And yet millions of people watched it ever week for a decade.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Same with ER and Gray's Anatomy and all of the other medical shows.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: There are, of course, exceptions. JAG, House, etc. But even with those, all of the character stuff they do is still driven by the rules of the setting. House is presented with science that *reflects his own problems* and his breakthrough moment *relates back to the science*, either by irony or inspiration.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: So yes, the science may be in service to the characters, but that doesn't mean that we can ignore science. If House wasn't a medical doctor his drug problem would be so shallow that he wouldn't have a narrative or a show. And he *still needs to do medicine*, and the things he does *or fails to do* as a doctor affect his narrative.

lines.author: Redshirt Army
lines.content: https://youtu.be/xbCWYm7B_B4

lines.author: Redshirt Army
lines.content: CSI: Asunaro

lines.author: Scarlet Storm
lines.content: Heh, basically

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Actually. Why am I talking about CSI and medical dramas? Considering the context I should be talking about Alien and Saving Private Ryan. Yeah, they're narrative masterpieces focused wholly on the characters and so on and so forth... but if you walk into Alien and don't have a power loader or some mud or a pulse rifle, or you try to save Private Ryan without bringing a helmet and a gun, the sum total of your narrative will be "ENTER STAGE LEFT. DIE. EXIT STAGE RIGHT.". And what you *do* bring helps dictate what the narrative is.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Plus, I hate to say this, but I have a major issue with really hard-core narrative thinking, and that issue is that it *sucks* for the people inside it.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Satisfying stories tend to have tension and obstacles. In order for the resolution to be a payoff, the audience has to feel like it was in doubt.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: That's fine when you're watching a movie. Living it, though? That's the difference between Inglorius Basterds and All Quiet on the Western Front.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: So, yeah, PMAS is driven by narrative and blah blah blah... but our job is to *fix things*, and that means we use every method we have at our disposal and we do it as efficiently and effectively as possible.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: And yes, I fully recognize that, as a magical universe with different laws of physics, what is efficient and effective may vary from reality.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Thinking that everything has to work just like IRL is the key failing of most rationalist fiction and I despise it.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Rather, I recognize Simon the Digger and Granny Weatherwax as some of the strongest rationalists in fiction. They know *precisely* how their universes work and they exploit the *hell* out of them.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: And I argue that PMAS *clearly and obviously* supports at least some level of SCIENCE.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: It's equally obviously not everything. That was Sereg's failure.

lines.author: Subrosian_Smithy
lines.content:
```
eh-hem. Real-world heuristics for instrumental rationality are not actually instrumental rationality. If you find yourself in a universe with Spiral Power, going beyond the impossible and kicking logic to the curb is the strictly rational move. You cannot rationalfic Gurren Lagann because there are no errors in reasoning to fix, whatsoever: they're doing the right things the whole time because their universe really does run on awesomesauce.
```

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Precisely.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: And PMAS, while it clearly has the importance of personal communication as a fundamental message and concerns itself with the people in the world... we were given the task of fixing *everything*, and we were given the *power to do that*.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: And you can't fix shit like the witch system with grief cleansing alone.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: We can argue all we want about the most efficient way to do it.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: But science is precisely as necessary to total victory as talking is - which is to say, it is.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Say you have one power, (A). You have two choices: In the set or not in the set. N(A) = 2. Now we add another power, to get (A, B). You have one option for the new power being included and one option for the new power being not included, N(B) = 2. Each of these options has for the *rest* of the powers all of the previous step's combinations, which is N(A). So two options for (A), times two for (B), to give N(A, B) = 4. Now we add another power C. You have two options for C, on or off, and each of them has all the possibilities for (A, B): N(A, B, C) = N(C) * N(A, B) = 2 * 4 = 8. Repeat: N(ABCD) = N(D) * N(ABC). Each of these provides two options, and you're multiplying them together; by induction we see that N(m elements) = 2 * 2 * ... * 2 with m twos in total, or 2^m.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Hilariously enough in this context, the set of all subsets (that is, the collection of all possible choices of the elements of a set) is called the "power set".

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Say you have one power, (A). You have two choices: In the set or not in the set. N(A) = 2. Now we add another power, to get (A, B). You have one option for the new power being included and one option for the new power being not included, N(B) = 2. Each of these options has for the *rest* of the powers all of the previous step's combinations, which is N(A). So two options for (A), times two for (B), to give N(A, B) = 4. Now we add another power C. You have two options for C, on or off, and each of them has all the possibilities for (A, B): N(A, B, C) = N(C) * N(A, B) = 2 * 4 = 8. Repeat: N(ABCD) = N(D) * N(ABC). Each of these provides two options, and you're multiplying them together; by induction we see that N(m elements) = 2 * 2 * ... * 2 with m twos in total, or 2^m.

lines.author: veByast
lines.content: Hilariously enough in this context, the set of all subsets (that is, the collection of all possible choices of the elements of a set) is called the "power set".

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Alright, so, apparently there's something about higher spatial dimensions and *something* in PMAS, but it doesn't have anything to do with witches, barriers, or grief seeds, and I'm not smart enough to figure it out.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: I cleared it with Firn before looking to talk about it here

lines.author: AppleTank
lines.content: wait what

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: It's apparently not a big deal, either way

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: But I've been completely nerdsniped by something I'm not smart enough to even figure out how to approach.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: So I figured I'd toss it to the community.

lines.author: Firnagzen
lines.content: well, it started with brina thinking about grief hyperspheres

lines.author: Kinruush
lines.content: As one does

lines.author: Firnagzen
lines.content: I hinted there's something to it, in the opposite direction from witches and barriers

lines.author: Firnagzen
lines.content: and that's all I'll say

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: I'd been idly pondering if it'd be possible to stack more grief into a given volume of 3-space by moving it aside along a higher dimensional axis.

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: Hm...

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: I mean, it...

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: _blinks several times._

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: Could it possibly have something to do with how Witch Barriers seem to have a reality/unreality axis? So, in the other direction, you're going hyperreal, or...?

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Opposite direction from witches and barriers.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: As in, the thing *about* the thought

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: Could this have something to do with the spacehug dimension?

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Not that sort of dimension, Aura.

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: I'm aware.

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: I mean like. How to put it.

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: Joke Response: "It's barriers all the way up."

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Right, I'm going to just go now.

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: But like. The defining thing about barriers is that they're _inward_ spaces that _sequester from the world_ and _are psychoactive to thoughts_ instead of acting to the real world.

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: So what's the opposite of that.

lines.author: alpha
lines.content: Hmm...

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Not that sort of opposite

lines.author: alpha
lines.content: Madokahalla?

lines.author: AppleTank
lines.content: Can we send our grief into the future to be dealth with later by making a grief hypercube?

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: As in, "has nothing whatsoever to do with witches or barriers"

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: Well you didn't give me much to go on aside from "opposite direction of barriers."

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: I was trying to plot a spectrum.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: As in, the possibility space *to be searched* is opposite from there

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Not that the thing in question is the opposite of a barrier

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: Okay, gotcha.

lines.author: All Witches' Night
lines.content:
I understand most of these words.
...on their own...

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Right now about the only thing that I can think of is that distances in n-space might not correspond to distances in 3-space, and our range limit isn't 3-space, but *absolute*, except that magic *doesn't work like that*.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: It's like the Aristotlean vs Newtonian motion thing with broom vs rocket in HPMOR

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: Remind me, how do we know magic doesn't work like that? Just before anyone argues the point.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
```
[3:41 PM] Godwinson: huh
[3:41 PM] Godwinson: contemplates
[3:41 PM] Firnagzen: Hmmm?
[3:41 PM] Godwinson: Grief hyperspheres.
[3:41 PM] Firnagzen: :)
[3:41 PM] Godwinson: Pack more grief into a given 3-space volume by shifting some of it to the side in higher dimensions
[3:42 PM] Firnagzen: Keep going with that thought
[3:42 PM] Godwinson: Oh!
[3:42 PM] Godwinson: That's how a barrier works?
[3:42 PM] Godwinson: Wait, no.
[3:43 PM] Godwinson: Movement within a barrier corresponds to 3-space
[3:43 PM] Godwinson: The barrier itself is parallel, then?
[3:43 PM] Godwinson: Or is...
[3:44 PM] Firnagzen: Interesting thought, but wrong direction
[3:44 PM] Godwinson: Maybe the witch-stuff that fills a grief seed is maximally stacked?
[3:44 PM] Godwinson: Fully saturates all spatial dimensions?
[3:44 PM] Firnagzen: Also, the shadow of a 4d object is 3d
[3:44 PM] Godwinson: Right, yeah, that...
[3:44 PM] Godwinson: ugh
[3:45 PM] Firnagzen: You can principally get it down to 2d, analogous to balancing a cube on one vertex
[3:45 PM] Godwinson: I don't think I have the appropriate knowledge base to properly explore this. :frowning:
[3:46 PM] Firnagzen: Nah, you do
[3:46 PM] Godwinson: OH!
[3:46 PM] Firnagzen: Opposite direction from witches and barriers...?
```

[3:53 PM] Firnagzen: hmmmm

lines.content:
```In the familiar three-dimensional space in which we live there are three coordinate axes—usually labeled x, y, and z—with each axis orthogonal (i.e. perpendicular) to the other two. The six cardinal directions in this space can be called up, down, east, west, north, and south. Positions along these axes can be called altitude, longitude, and latitude. Lengths measured along these axes can be called height, width, and depth.

Comparatively, four-dimensional space has an extra coordinate axis, orthogonal to the other three, which is usually labeled w. To describe the two additional cardinal directions, Charles Howard Hinton coined the terms ana and kata, from the Greek words meaning "up toward" and "down from", respectively. A position along the w axis can be called spissitude, as coined by Henry More.```

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
```Not as much as being blown up, and boy do I hate being blown up, but catching a bullet through the gut isn't something I'd recommend to anyone looking for a fun time. I snap a low-powered bolt of magic at the bastard who shot me, the blast leaving my hand to bowl him off his feet while I spin and manifest a hammer in my free hand. The spin ends as I loose the hammer at Lung, and it catches him in the lower back with a sickening crack that causes his legs to go limp beneath him, while the bolt of magic hits the shooter in the chest, sending him sprawling.

I shut off my ability to feel pain and leap back and away from the fight, landing on top of a dead streetlamp. I resist the urge to start ranting about truth and justice. I mean, it's the thing to do when perching on top of a streetlamp. Unless you're Batman, then the thing to do would be to brood about your dead parents.

Instead, I pull at the trickle of grief that's built up in my soul-gem from the fight thus far, turning it into more gem shielding, and then peeling away the unneeded excess. I'm not going to leave my soul vulnerable for an instant here, but I need the grief. The lack of lights in the area and my rapid movement has left the ABB members searching about for me, but I only have a few moments to spare.

I take my second cubic centimeter of grief and dissolve it into fog, sending it into the bleeding hole in my gut. I quickly find the bullet and pull it out of me, then I find the torn blood vessels and pull their surfaces together, then cauterize them into place with a focused burst of microwaves. I do the same thing to burn out the pain receptors all along the wound channel, then pull the grief out and close the entry wound. Quick and dirty battlefield surgery, but at least I won't have to worry about the injury slowing me down. It's not the first time I've had to do something like this, and knowing my luck it won't be the last.```

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content:
```Jesus was the result of a scandal, and Jesus never figured out his dad was John the Baptist until after he died and ascended into a higher being. He never returned due to depression.
The noble, sincere, selfless soul of the Christhead remained dead when he was raised, and it is this which Mankind prays for the return of.
Mary Magdeline was an android.
M.A.R.Y.: Multiform Autonomous Robotic Yeshualizer.
Her purpose was originally to support the mythology of Jesus with artificially induced miracles, then steal his body, revive him, etc.
When he ollied out, she decided to set up an Anime Dueling Tournament to determine the new Jesus.
This was basically Revolutionary Girl Utena, straight up.
People were told she was offering the power to change and rule the world and that she would obey the winner, and they fought over her, being spiritually tested as they pursued their petty desires, not realizing that their selfishness guaranteed their failure. Only a pure, sincere, noble, selfless, compassionate soul that loved all of mankind, and wanted nothing but to save and forgive them, could claim her.
The winner was Utena Tenjou (whose surname basically means Heaven).
She got misremembered as the male prophet Termax because of course she did, and so the religion is basically very Engrishly named "Heavenism" in weebspeak.
When she learned the true nature of M.A.R.Y., she fused with the revived Christmind, activated the passcodes that turned Mary into a giant mech, and then went to go fight Queen Satan as the ascended MAXIMUM GODHEAD HYPERJESUS.```

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: A lot of dungeons spring up because the universe is a shared dream...meaning that rather than being a shared reality with people in it, per se, everyone is a bunch of souls being shown the same hologram, and their own psyches disrupt it and cause de-syncs and distortions that cause some people to experience smaller, more personalized dreams. When things are brought out of these dungeons into the wider world, contradictions pile up.

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: On top of that, when Kalpas end and shift and the world ends and begins anew, some things hidden in lower dream layers and sub-pockets manage to endure and find their way back up to the surface.

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: Perhaps the Sun is not meant to be a Girl in this dream's iteration, but the Sun-Girl set below in the dark unconscious, and as the Sun does, she rose again on the new 'day', refusing to remain in the proverbial Night.

lines.author: vebyast
lines.content: Then we just have to argue to her that Oriko *is being seriously hurt right now*.

lines.author: vebyast
lines.content: From what I'm hearing, Sayaka wants Oriko to suffer *just* enough for it to be "justice" instead of "torture".

lines.author: vebyast
lines.content: So the way to deal with this would be to convince her that Oriko has suffered enough.

lines.author: vebyast
lines.content: It helps that Oriko appears to be holding to her motive of "I want to make the world a better place" and just - by Sayaka's analysis - fucked up the implementation. My read on Sayaka is that she'd be perfectly willing to do some pretty extreme things in the name of Good.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: The main limitation on that would be that certain actions are inherently "not good"

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: There's a reason why deontological ethics, or at least *components* of an ethical system that are rule-ethics, are so common for people, because they serve as hard limiters

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Sayaka's natural inclination is toward the naive-idealistic "Heroic Morality", as presented in typical media

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: (Then again, she's also in her early teens -- *most* of us has fairly simplistic ideas and ideals at that time, simply because of a lack of time spent with a brain that is fully capable of modelling others effectively)

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: There are eight people whose utility is directly impacted by the issue of Oriko and Kirika's treatment

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Oriko, Kirika, Sayaka, Homura, Hitomi, Mami, Madoka, and Sabrina.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Oriko and Kirika are obvious in terms of how their treatment impacts them

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Sayaka, Homura, and Hitomi as well, as the immediately aggrieved parties, with Mami and Madoka as indirectly aggrieved parties

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: With Sabrina largely being impacted by the way that different approaches impact everyone else

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: The Kures' preferences would largely be toward greater leniency, though not to as full of an extent as might generally be assumed, due to Oriko's tendency to think she deserves to be punished, largely due to various pre-existing factors which also informed her approach to the actions that were at the root of all of this

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Sayaka and Hitomi have been directly impacted by the Kures' actions in this timeline, while Homura's stake in this is largely due to the "beyond-the-pale" level of transgressions performed by alternate-timeline versions of the Kures.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Sayaka's primary motivation on the matter is personal loss of emotionally significant personal property, dislocation of her family and ensuing debts incurred, as well as a general belief in the ideal of "Justice" mandating that people who have committed similar acts be imprisoned (to ensure no additional crimes are committed, as punishment, and as rehabilitation, with the exact balance of rationales and desired effects likely varying by instance).

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Hitomi's primary motivation on the matter does not appear to be the deliberate injury inflicted on her by Kirika, instead being the damages inflicted on her friend as well as general principles and ideals on the matter, to the extent of becoming *very* incensed at the thought that Sabrina carried out a summary retaliatory maiming on her behalf. It's also possible that she is unconvinced that the matter ought to be decided upon by Sabrina, rather than by mundane authorities.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Homura's *stated* primary motivation is ensuring that Madoka is safe from any efforts made by the Kures to harm her, however it is also quite clear that there is significant personal animus against Oriko in particular for her alternate timeline counterpart's actions.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Mami and Madoka's investment in the issue is largely similar, in that people whom they care about were harmed by the Kures.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Though Mami's position as "lead magical girl of Mitakihara" colors the particulars of her responses

lines.author: Onmur
lines.content: Hitomi prolly thinks the japanese justice system should be the one judging.  We'll probably have to talk with her about megucafacts

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: (Yes, all of this is stuff that people already know, but sometimes it's helpful to specifically *state* it for review, to see if you've overlooked something -- and in exactly the same spirit, if there's anything that I've missed there, please point it out.)

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Now, with motives established, let's look at our limiting factors.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: We have harshly limited manpower to spend on maintaining a guard, to the extent that their existing punishment has largely operated solely due to the full cooperation of the Kures.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Our existing assortment of powers, once accounting for other limiting factors on *them*, are not particularly useful in finding a substitute

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: (e.g. Locking them up inside our barrier could very well work, but runs into the potential issues that creating a barrier might result in)

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: The supermajority of involved parties are opposed to capital punishment, at least in this instance, with one notable exception.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Kirika's power makes any magical measures put into place *highly* dubious in effectiveness.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Outside magical girls are aware of the existence of the Kures, and our treatment of them *will* have ramifications in terms of our group's reputation.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: (If anyone thinks of additional limiting factors, I will add them to the list in this line.)

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: An additional complicating factor is that the Kures have on several occasions provided us with support in *our* endeavors (Oriko's precognitive support *especially* with regards to Sayaka being witch kissed, Kirika providing assistance in Sendai, Oriko and Kirika providing assistance in Asunaro)

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: (If anyone thinks of additional complicating factors, I will add them to the list in this line.)

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: With all of the above in mind, there are a few potential ways to alter the status quo that have been brought up before.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Relocation. That is, maintain house arrest as current, but change the location of the house arrest to one that is less psychologically harmful to Oriko than her family home.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Exile. Kick the Kures out of Mitakihara under threat of suitably severe penalties if they return.

lines.author: alpha
lines.content: Relocation to the Stronghold is what I think I'll advocate for

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Execution. Homura's preferred option, at least initially, though current factors have likely made it so that she won't feel comfortable advocating for it.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: De-gemming. Effectively an inescapable imprisonment and/or reversible execution depending on philosophical stance, rapidly runs into a wide array of ethical issues, as well as practical issues, such as objections from others involved or group reputation.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content: Probation. Lift house arrest while placing tracking devices on the Kures.

lines.author: Sabrina
lines.content:
(If anyone thinks of additional *fundamental* options, rather than modifications and/or combinations of the above, I will add them to the list in this line.)
Formal Imprisonment. Assign full-time guards to keep an eye on the Kures. Requires sufficient magical girlpower to put into practice.
Mind Alteration. Find a magical girl whose powers permit her to rewrite behaviors. Manages to run into even more ethical and practical issues than de-gemming, which is impressive.

lines.author: AuraTwilight
lines.content: Technically brainguca-ing them, but fucking E.W.

lines.author: Yvonne
lines.content: I can't say I see much benefit to relocation outside of things that venture into proper imprisonment, with either a parent/family member or a magical girl assigned to supervise them.

lines.author: Firnagzen
lines.content: >Because it would be funny if when we offered her those IRCs her immediate vision was Homura emerging from her computer guns blazing...

lines.author: Firnagzen
lines.content: /homuno

lines.author: alpha
lines.content: lol

lines.author: Firnagzen
lines.content: Sometimes, firnbot has the absolute perfect command

lines.author: Yvonne
lines.content: Anyways, I think imprisonment might count as something that is fundamentally different than other options. Since it would involve a human being physically watching them 24/7, or close to that. *Manpower* is a problem with the option, but it might be worth adding to the pile and batting about.

lines.author: Yvonne
lines.content: Though a point on Manpower itself is that, while it has been sharply limited in the past, as time goes on a number of factors will make that less of a problem.

lines.author: Yvonne
lines.content: Firstly, and most inevitably, simple movement of refugees will add to Mitakihara's magical girl population making for people who may or may not be useful. Though it may be worth noting that they will start with the category of "girls old or well connected enough to know Nadia"

lines.author: Yvonne
lines.content: Secondly, our own actions will play a part. If we end up protecting and supplying newly contracted local girls, or a long shot but one we will be trying for regardless, successfully dewitch girls, that will add to Mitakihara's population as well.

lines.author: Yvonne
lines.content: Thirdly, and the one that requires most effort from us, is simply hiring out, which will provide by far the highest quality manpower but is also something we'll need to commit significant time and resources to maintaining. In this case, while we'll do this already just in order to defeat Walpurgisnacht that doesn't necessarily translate to useful work in other areas (such as chaperones for probation or guards for imprisonment)

lines.author: Sabrina

lines.content: There's a reason why deontological ethics, or at least *components* of an ethical system that are rule-ethics, are so common for people, because they serve as hard limiters
lines.author: Sabrina

lines.author: Sabrina

lines.content: (Then again, she's also in her early teens -- *most* of us has fairly simplistic ideas and ideals at that time, simply because of a lack of time spent with a brain that is fully capable of modelling others effectively)
